title: Split Panes
narrative:
In this specification you can can not only see how to use the Swing-Tree API to 
   create and configure split panes but also how to bind them to your view model model.
   The alignment of a split pane for example can be bound to a property in your view model.

features.id: A horizontally aligned split pane can be created through the "splitPane" factory method.

blocks.text: We create a horizontally aligned split pane UI node.
The split pane is not null.
The split pane is a JSplitPane.
The split pane is horizontally aligned b, meaning it splits vertically.

features.id: A vertically aligned split pane can be created through the "splitPane" factory method.

blocks.text: We create a vertically aligned split pane UI node.
The split pane is not null.
The split pane is a JSplitPane.
The split pane is vertically aligned, meaning it splits horizontally.

features.id: An alignment property can be used to dynamically model the alignment of your split pane.

extraInfo:
Note that the property shown in this example would be part of your view model.
            So you can simply modify it as part of your business logic and the split pane
            will automatically update its alignment.

blocks.text: We create a simple view model property holding the alignment of our split pane.
We create a split pane UI node bound to the property.
The split pane is not null.
The split pane is a JSplitPane.
The split pane is horizontally aligned, meaning it splits vertically.
We change the alignment property to "VERTICAL".
The split pane is vertically aligned, meaning it splits horizontally.

features.id: A split pane can be configured with a divider size.

blocks.text:
We first set a scaling factor to simulate a platform with higher DPI.
            So when your screen has a higher pixel density then this factor
            is used by SwingTree to ensure that the UI is upscaled accordingly! 
            Please note that the line below only exists for testing purposes, 
            SwingTree will determine a suitable 
            scaling factor for the current system automatically for you,
            so you do not have to specify this factor manually.
We create a split pane UI node with a divider size of 10.
The split pane is not null.
The split pane is a JSplitPane.
The split pane is horizontally aligned, meaning it splits vertically.
The divider size is 10.

features.id: The divider location of a split pane can dynamically be modelled using an integer property.

extraInfo:
Note that the property shown in this example would be part of your view model.
            So you can simply modify it as part of your business logic and the split pane
            will automatically update its divider location based on an observer
            registered on the property.

blocks.text: We create a simple view model property holding the divider location of our split pane.

features.id: You can dynamically model the divider size of a split pane in your view model.
